comment: /* The history of ethics */ - link Jinas now goes to Tirthankar

diff.*:
Line 5: Line 5:  
The formal study of ethics in a serious and analytical sense began with the early Greeks, and later Romans. Important Greek ethicists include the [[Sophists]] and [[Socrates]], [[Plato]] and [[Aristotle]], who developed [[ethical naturalism]]. The study of ethics was developed further by [[Epicurus]] and the [[Epicureanism|epicurean]] movement, and by [[Zeno of Citium|Zeno]] and the [[stoicism|stoics]].
 
The formal study of ethics in a serious and analytical sense began with the early Greeks, and later Romans. Important Greek ethicists include the [[Sophists]] and [[Socrates]], [[Plato]] and [[Aristotle]], who developed [[ethical naturalism]]. The study of ethics was developed further by [[Epicurus]] and the [[Epicureanism|epicurean]] movement, and by [[Zeno of Citium|Zeno]] and the [[stoicism|stoics]].
    −
Although not developed in a formal and analytical sense, the subject of ethics was of great concern to the Hindu people in Ancient India. For the first time in world history, they described the highest ethical standards called "absolute ethics" by [[Albert Schweitzer]]. Millennia later, the [[Society of Friends]] or the Quakers reached as high as the [[Jinas]].
+
Although not developed in a formal and analytical sense, the subject of ethics was of great concern to the Hindu people in Ancient India. For the first time in world history, they described the highest ethical standards called "absolute ethics" by [[Albert Schweitzer]]. Millennia later, the [[Society of Friends]] or the Quakers reached as high as the [[Tirthankar|Jinas]].
 
See also [[Ethics in religion]]
 
See also [[Ethics in religion]]
